title.value: Causal Discovery in Gene Regulatory Networks with GFlowNet: Towards Scalability in Large Systems
title.justification: This is the official title of the paper as mentioned at the beginning of the document.
title.quote: Causal Discovery in Gene Regulatory Networks with GFlowNet: Towards Scalability in Large Systems

extractions.description: The paper introduces Swift-DynGFN, a new framework designed to enhance causal structure learning in Gene Regulatory Networks (GRNs) while addressing scalability issues. It leverages gene-wise independence and parallelization to reduce computational costs, demonstrated through experiments on both real single-cell RNA velocity data and synthetic GRN datasets.

type.justification: The paper provides empirical evaluations of the proposed Swift-DynGFN framework through experiments on real single-cell RNA velocity data and synthetic GRN datasets.
type.quote: Experiments on real single-cell RNA velocity and synthetic GRN datasets showcase the advancement in learning causal structure in GRNs and scalability in larger systems.

name.justification: The research focuses on causal relationships within Gene Regulatory Networks (GRNs), a crucial aspect of computational biology.
name.quote: Understanding causal relationships within Gene Regulatory Networks (GRNs) is essential for unraveling the gene interactions in cellular processes.

name.justification: A significant part of the paper is dedicated to improving causal structure learning within GRNs.
name.quote: We introduce Swift-DynGFN as a novel framework that enhances causal structure learning in GRNs while addressing scalability concerns.

name.justification: The paper utilizes Generative Flow Networks (GFlowNets) to tackle complex causal structure learning in GRNs.
name.quote: We propose Swift-DynGFN to navigate the intricacies of causal structures in GRNs and address scalability. Swift-DynGFN improves the architecture of GFlowNet and draws upon the Bayesian dynamic structure learning framework.

name.justification: Swift-DynGFN is the primary model introduced and evaluated in the paper.
name.quote: Introduce Swift-DynGFN that improves causal structure learning in GRNs by encouraging gene-wise causal influence and tackles the scalability challenge by enriching parallelization to reduce time and space costs.

is_contributed.justification: Swift-DynGFN is a novel framework proposed by the authors.
is_contributed.quote: Introduce Swift-DynGFN that improves causal structure learning in GRNs by encouraging gene-wise causal influence and tackles the scalability challenge by enriching parallelization to reduce time and space costs.

is_executed.justification: The paper includes experiments using Swift-DynGFN on real single-cell RNA velocity data and synthetic GRN datasets.
is_executed.quote: Experiments on real single-cell RNA velocity and synthetic GRN datasets showcase the advancement in learning causal structure in GRNs and scalability in larger systems.

is_compared.justification: The performance of Swift-DynGFN is compared to other baseline models like DynGFN, DynBCD, and DynDiBS.
is_compared.quote: We compare our method to DynGFN, DynBCD, and DynDiBS, reported in DynGFN paper.

referenced_paper_title.value: Dyngfn: Towards bayesian inference of gene regulatory networks with gflownets
referenced_paper_title.justification: The model builds upon prior work on DynGFN.
referenced_paper_title.quote: We compare our method to DynGFN, DynBCD, and DynDiBS, reported in DynGFN paper.

name.value: Cell cycle dataset of human Fibroblasts
name.justification: The experiments on single-cell RNA-velocity data use this dataset.
name.quote: We investigate the cell cycle dataset of human Fibroblasts that contains records of 5000 cells and more than 10,000 genes.

referenced_paper_title.value: Cell cycle gene regulation dynamics revealed by rna velocity and deep-learning
referenced_paper_title.justification: The dataset is associated with RNA velocity data studies.
referenced_paper_title.quote: We investigate the cell cycle dataset of human Fibroblasts that contains records of 5000 cells and more than 10,000 genes. Following Atanackovic et al., we utilize a group of five genes, where Cdc25A activates Cdk1, which, in turn, inhibits Cdc25C, while the Mcm complex is correlated with Cdc25A but does not directly interact with Cdk1 in the cell cycle regulation.

name.justification: The paper also includes experiments on synthetic data generated to evaluate scalability.
name.quote: The experiment on synthetic GRN data proves the scalability potential of Swift-DynGFN.

referenced_paper_title.value: Dyngfn: Towards bayesian inference of gene regulatory networks with gflownets
referenced_paper_title.justification: The synthetic dataset aligns with methodologies discussed in related works like DynGFN.
referenced_paper_title.quote: Dataset We adopt the dataset generation using the indeterminacy model from Atanackovic et al. and create a non-linear dynamical system dx = sigmoid(Ax).

name.justification: PyTorch is used for implementing the models and experiments.
name.quote: The implementation is built using PyTorch.

referenced_paper_title.justification: No specific reference paper for PyTorch is mentioned.
